snippet: Growth in remote regions has produced a fight over land in which leaders of the indigenous Guarani people have been killed, leaving a stain on Brazil’s rise as an economic powerhouse.
abstract: Expansion of huge cattle ranches and industrial-scale farms in remote regions has produced a land scramble that is leaving the descendants of Brazil’s original inhabitants desperate to recover tribal terrains, in some cases squatting on contested properties; nonindigenous landowners, many of whom live on land settled decades ago by their own ancestors under the government’s so-called colonization programs, are just as attached to their claims; conflicts often result in violent clashes.

byline.contributor: Lis Horta Moriconi contributed reporting from Rio de Janeiro.

lead_paragraph: Growth in remote regions has produced a fight over land in which leaders of the indigenous Guarani people have been killed, leaving a stain on Brazil’s rise as an economic powerhouse.

headline.seo: In Brazil, Violence Hits Tribes in Scramble for Land
headline.main: Violence Hits Brazil Tribes in Scramble for Land
headline.print_headline: Violence Hits Brazil Tribes In Scramble For Land
